trans-unit.source: Navigation in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps is based on a flexible model of navigation structures, navigation elements, and system-level features.
trans-unit.target: Navigation in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps is based on a flexible model of navigation structures, navigation elements, and system-level features.

trans-unit.source: Navigation design basics for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
trans-unit.target: Navigation design basics for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

trans-unit.source: Navigation history and backwards navigation
trans-unit.target: Navigation history and backwards navigation

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: On the Web, individual web sites provide their own navigation systems, such as tables of contents, buttons, menus, simple lists of links, and so on.
trans-unit.target: On the Web, individual web sites provide their own navigation systems, such as tables of contents, buttons, menus, simple lists of links, and so on.

trans-unit.source: The navigation experience can vary wildly from website to website.
trans-unit.target: The navigation experience can vary wildly from website to website.

trans-unit.source: However, there is one consistent navigation experience: back.
trans-unit.target: However, there is one consistent navigation experience: back.

trans-unit.source: Most browsers provide a back button that behaves the same way regardless of the website.
trans-unit.target: Most browsers provide a back button that behaves the same way regardless of the website.

trans-unit.source: For similar reasons, the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) provides a consistent back navigation system for traversing the user's navigation history within an app and, depending on the device, from app to app.
trans-unit.target: For similar reasons, the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) provides a consistent back navigation system for traversing the user's navigation history within an app and, depending on the device, from app to app.

trans-unit.source: The UI for the system back button is optimized for each form factor and input device type, but the navigation experience is global and consistent across devices and UWP apps.
trans-unit.target: The UI for the system back button is optimized for each form factor and input device type, but the navigation experience is global and consistent across devices and UWP apps.

trans-unit.source: Here are the primary form factors with the back button UI:
trans-unit.target: Here are the primary form factors with the back button UI:

trans-unit.source: Devices
trans-unit.target: Devices

trans-unit.source: Back button behavior
trans-unit.target: Back button behavior

trans-unit.source: Phone
trans-unit.target: Phone

trans-unit.source: Always present.
trans-unit.target: Always present.

trans-unit.source: A software or hardware button at the bottom of the device.
trans-unit.target: A software or hardware button at the bottom of the device.

trans-unit.source: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.
trans-unit.target: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.

trans-unit.source: Tablet
trans-unit.target: Tablet

trans-unit.source: Always present in Tablet mode.
trans-unit.target: Always present in Tablet mode.

trans-unit.source: A software button in the navigation bar at the bottom of the device.
trans-unit.target: A software button in the navigation bar at the bottom of the device.

trans-unit.source: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.
trans-unit.target: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.

trans-unit.source: PC, Laptop, Tablet
trans-unit.target: PC, Laptop, Tablet

trans-unit.source: Optional in Desktop mode.
trans-unit.target: Optional in Desktop mode.

trans-unit.source: A software button in the title bar of the app.
trans-unit.target: A software button in the title bar of the app.

trans-unit.source: Back navigation within the app only.
trans-unit.target: Back navigation within the app only.

trans-unit.source: Does not support app-to-app navigation.
trans-unit.target: Does not support app-to-app navigation.

trans-unit.source: Surface Hub
trans-unit.target: Surface Hub

trans-unit.source: Optional.
trans-unit.target: Optional.

trans-unit.source: Disabled by default.
trans-unit.target: Disabled by default.

trans-unit.source: Must opt in to enable it.
trans-unit.target: Must opt in to enable it.

trans-unit.source: A software button in the title bar of the app.
trans-unit.target: A software button in the title bar of the app.

trans-unit.source: Back navigation within the app only.
trans-unit.target: Back navigation within the app only.

trans-unit.source: Does not support app-to-app navigation.
trans-unit.target: Does not support app-to-app navigation.

trans-unit.source: Here are some alternative input types that don't rely on a back button UI, but still provide the exact same functionality.
trans-unit.target: Here are some alternative input types that don't rely on a back button UI, but still provide the exact same functionality.

trans-unit.source: Input devices
trans-unit.target: Input devices

trans-unit.source: Keyboard
trans-unit.target: Keyboard

trans-unit.source: Windows key + Backspace
trans-unit.target: Windows key + Backspace

trans-unit.source: Cortana
trans-unit.target: Cortana

trans-unit.source: Say, "Hey Cortana, go back"
trans-unit.target: Say, "Hey Cortana, go back"

trans-unit.source: When your app runs on a phone, tablet, or on a PC or laptop that has system back enabled, the system notifies your app when the back button is pressed.
trans-unit.target: When your app runs on a phone, tablet, or on a PC or laptop that has system back enabled, the system notifies your app when the back button is pressed.

trans-unit.source: The user expects the back button to navigate to the previous location in the app's navigation history.
trans-unit.target: The user expects the back button to navigate to the previous location in the app's navigation history.

trans-unit.source: It's up to you to decide which navigation actions to add to the navigation history and how to respond to the back button press.
trans-unit.target: It's up to you to decide which navigation actions to add to the navigation history and how to respond to the back button press.

trans-unit.source: How to enable system back navigation support
trans-unit.target: How to enable system back navigation support

trans-unit.source: Apps must enable back navigation for all hardware and software system back buttons.
trans-unit.target: Apps must enable back navigation for all hardware and software system back buttons.

trans-unit.source: Do this by registering a listener for the [**BackRequested**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn893596) event and defining a corresponding handler.
trans-unit.target: Do this by registering a listener for the [**BackRequested**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn893596) event and defining a corresponding handler.

trans-unit.source: Here we register a global listener for the [**BackRequested**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn893596) event in the App.xaml code-behind file.
trans-unit.target: Here we register a global listener for the [**BackRequested**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn893596) event in the App.xaml code-behind file.

trans-unit.source: You can register for this event in each page if you want to exclude specific pages from back navigation, or you want to execute page-level code before displaying the page.
trans-unit.target: You can register for this event in each page if you want to exclude specific pages from back navigation, or you want to execute page-level code before displaying the page.

trans-unit.source: Here's the corresponding [**BackRequested**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn893596) event handler that calls [**GoBack**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn996568) on the root frame of the app.
trans-unit.target: Here's the corresponding [**BackRequested**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn893596) event handler that calls [**GoBack**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn996568) on the root frame of the app.

trans-unit.source: This handler is invoked on a global back event.
trans-unit.target: This handler is invoked on a global back event.

trans-unit.source: If the in-app back stack is empty, the system might navigate to the previous app in the app stack or to the Start screen.
trans-unit.target: If the in-app back stack is empty, the system might navigate to the previous app in the app stack or to the Start screen.

trans-unit.source: There is no app back stack in Desktop mode and the user stays in the app even when the in-app back stack is depleted.
trans-unit.target: There is no app back stack in Desktop mode and the user stays in the app even when the in-app back stack is depleted.

trans-unit.source: How to enable the title bar back button
trans-unit.target: How to enable the title bar back button

trans-unit.source: Devices that support Desktop mode (typically PCs and laptops, but also some tablets) and have the setting enabled (**Settings > System > Tablet mode**), do not provide a global navigation bar with the system back button.
trans-unit.target: Devices that support Desktop mode (typically PCs and laptops, but also some tablets) and have the setting enabled (**Settings > System > Tablet mode**), do not provide a global navigation bar with the system back button.

trans-unit.source: In Desktop mode, every app runs in a window with a title bar.
trans-unit.target: In Desktop mode, every app runs in a window with a title bar.

trans-unit.source: You can provide an alternative back button for your app that is displayed in this title bar.
trans-unit.target: You can provide an alternative back button for your app that is displayed in this title bar.

trans-unit.source: The title bar back button is only available in apps running on devices in Desktop mode, and only supports in-app navigation history—it does not support app-to-app navigation history.
trans-unit.target: The title bar back button is only available in apps running on devices in Desktop mode, and only supports in-app navigation history—it does not support app-to-app navigation history.

trans-unit.source: **Important** The title bar back button is not displayed by default.
trans-unit.target: **Important** The title bar back button is not displayed by default.

trans-unit.source: You must opt in.
trans-unit.target: You must opt in.

trans-unit.source: no system back in desktop mode
trans-unit.target: no system back in desktop mode

trans-unit.source: system back in desktop mode
trans-unit.target: system back in desktop mode

trans-unit.source: Desktop mode, no back navigation.
trans-unit.target: Desktop mode, no back navigation.

trans-unit.source: Desktop mode, back navigation enabled.
trans-unit.target: Desktop mode, back navigation enabled.

trans-unit.source: Override the [**OnNavigatedTo**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227508) event and set [**AppViewBackButtonVisibility**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn986448) to [**Visible**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn986276) in the code-behind file for each page that you want to enable the title bar back button.
trans-unit.target: Override the [**OnNavigatedTo**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227508) event and set [**AppViewBackButtonVisibility**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn986448) to [**Visible**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn986276) in the code-behind file for each page that you want to enable the title bar back button.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we list each page in the back stack and enable the back button if the [**CanGoBack**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242685) property of the frame has a value of **true**.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we list each page in the back stack and enable the back button if the [**CanGoBack**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242685) property of the frame has a value of **true**.

trans-unit.source: Guidelines for custom back navigation behavior
trans-unit.target: Guidelines for custom back navigation behavior

trans-unit.source: If you choose to provide your own back stack navigation, the experience should be consistent with other apps.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to provide your own back stack navigation, the experience should be consistent with other apps.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you follow the following patterns for navigation actions:
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you follow the following patterns for navigation actions:

trans-unit.source: Navigation action
trans-unit.target: Navigation action

trans-unit.source: Add to navigation history?
trans-unit.target: Add to navigation history?

trans-unit.source: Page to page, different peer groups
trans-unit.target: Page to page, different peer groups

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: In this illustration, the user navigates from level 1 of the app to level 2, crossing peer groups, so the navigation is added to the navigation history.
trans-unit.target: In this illustration, the user navigates from level 1 of the app to level 2, crossing peer groups, so the navigation is added to the navigation history.

trans-unit.source: In the next illustration, the user navigates between two peer groups at the same level, again crossing peer groups, so the navigation is added to the navigation history.
trans-unit.target: In the next illustration, the user navigates between two peer groups at the same level, again crossing peer groups, so the navigation is added to the navigation history.

trans-unit.source: Page to page, same peer group, no on-screen navigation element
trans-unit.target: Page to page, same peer group, no on-screen navigation element

trans-unit.source: The user navigates from one page to another with the same peer group.
trans-unit.target: The user navigates from one page to another with the same peer group.

trans-unit.source: There is no navigation element that is always present (such as tabs/pivots or a docked navigation pane) that provides direct navigation to both pages.
trans-unit.target: There is no navigation element that is always present (such as tabs/pivots or a docked navigation pane) that provides direct navigation to both pages.

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: In the following illustration, the user navigates between two pages in the same peer group.
trans-unit.target: In the following illustration, the user navigates between two pages in the same peer group.

trans-unit.source: The pages don't use tabs or a docked navigation pane, so the navigation is added to the navigation history.
trans-unit.target: The pages don't use tabs or a docked navigation pane, so the navigation is added to the navigation history.

trans-unit.source: Page to page, same peer group, with an on-screen navigation element
trans-unit.target: Page to page, same peer group, with an on-screen navigation element

trans-unit.source: The user navigates from one page to another in the same peer group.
trans-unit.target: The user navigates from one page to another in the same peer group.

trans-unit.source: Both pages are shown in the same navigation element.
trans-unit.target: Both pages are shown in the same navigation element.

trans-unit.source: For example, both pages use the same tabs/pivots element, or both pages appear in a docked navigation pane.
trans-unit.target: For example, both pages use the same tabs/pivots element, or both pages appear in a docked navigation pane.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: When the user presses back, go back to the last page before the user navigated to the current peer group.
trans-unit.target: When the user presses back, go back to the last page before the user navigated to the current peer group.

trans-unit.source: Show a transient UI
trans-unit.target: Show a transient UI

trans-unit.source: The app displays a pop-up or child window, such as a dialog, splash screen, or on-screen keyboard, or the app enters a special mode, such as multiple selection mode.
trans-unit.target: The app displays a pop-up or child window, such as a dialog, splash screen, or on-screen keyboard, or the app enters a special mode, such as multiple selection mode.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: When the user presses the back button, dismiss the transient UI (hide the on-screen keyboard, cancel the dialog, etc) and return to the page that spawned the transient UI.
trans-unit.target: When the user presses the back button, dismiss the transient UI (hide the on-screen keyboard, cancel the dialog, etc) and return to the page that spawned the transient UI.

trans-unit.source: Enumerate items
trans-unit.target: Enumerate items

trans-unit.source: The app displays content for an on-screen item, such as the details for the selected item in master/details list.
trans-unit.target: The app displays content for an on-screen item, such as the details for the selected item in master/details list.

trans-unit.source: No.
trans-unit.target: No.

trans-unit.source: Enumerating items is similar to navigating within a peer group.
trans-unit.target: Enumerating items is similar to navigating within a peer group.

trans-unit.source: When the user presses back, navigate to the page that preceded the current page that has the item enumeration.
trans-unit.target: When the user presses back, navigate to the page that preceded the current page that has the item enumeration.

trans-unit.source: Resuming
trans-unit.target: Resuming

trans-unit.source: When the user switches to another app and returns to your app, we recommend returning to the last page in the navigation history.
trans-unit.target: When the user switches to another app and returns to your app, we recommend returning to the last page in the navigation history.

trans-unit.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to UWP apps and Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to UWP apps and Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the [Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=258743).\]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the [Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=258743).\]
